title: ZIP City: Houseless Not Homeless

author: Lavinia Scaletti, Royal College of Art

segmentation: I am presenting the city houseless, not homeless, which was my MA project at the Royal College of Art.
I'm so zip city.
It's an you architecture and urban design strategy program that imagines a new way of living in cities.
Based on the idea that we wanted houses anymore, so the starting site and point is London actually questions.
How can we approach the housing crisis?
The city is actually experiencing through moving away from darling and not dwelling and not building houses and reimagine the concepts of ownership, home and and sharing in general.
So just.

As context as I said, the starting point was the London housing crisis and the fact that today housing, which is usually a fundamental right, it's been compromised by austerity programs and just speculative agenda, so it's seen in a completely different optic nowadays.

So just to give you a few numbers today in London, less than 1/3 of the housing target is actually met, which means that if we speculate an up in 2030 up to 30, three 100,000 people might be left with no housing.

And this not only concerns like the precarious side of the population, but also an increasing part of the middle class is young, professional, and even families, so it actually concerns a wider and wider portion of the population.

So in terms of the proposal, the proposal works on 3 scales, so the first one is urban.

So from house functions density function, this is just a conceptual map I've done at the beginning and this idea of bisecting the by moving away from Delhi dwelling the project is London wide, and the Newhouse less is able to freely circulate around this main trust for hubs where actually buildings are placed around these hubs, and it's taking advantage of the existing and the plant infrastructure, so services and transport, and that will allow this condition as well to be possible.

The second scale is the architectural, so I've been exploring new technologies of architectures for the House less, and the idea of developing common aspects and concepts that then will be adapted to specific.
Specific context, so I've been looking at what happens with the Post office if you don't have a fixed address.
The living storage, or this idea of people land stop, which is how do you charge your phone.

This idea took Elephant and Castle in London as a site for implementing this more general ideas, and it's an interesting side because he's undergoing regeneration and they're building new houses and more services are going to come.
I don't know if that's a good or bad thing, but it's that's going to happen.
So how actually do you?
Are you gonna like?
Use it as a as a resource?
So zip storage, so I'm going to present a few of the technologies I've been exploring in more detail.

Zip Storage is a new storage tower where it's a new built in, is placed in at the center of Elephant and Castle roundabout, so it's a big building to show this massive condition of 300,000 people not having a house.
And it's built in reaction to existing storage spaces, which are usually really dark and we never corridors.
And they are really hard to access on a daily basis, so this idea of actually promoting it as a as a new space for socializing, where people can find home.
So just to give you an idea.
There is a laundry room factory can.
There are some home functions that you can still do, and while maybe you do your laundry, you can go into.
TV storage room.

With this idea of relaxing or this homely feeling of gathering together on the TV and the concept is that the people who are helpless now bring their stuff together and they are made available for the Houseless community, while their house less so.
It could be a year.
It could be the whole life.
And just like this idea of having different storage rooms to accommodate the different requirements of all these people.
And then zip buff.
It's completely different because it's it.
It reuses Elephant and Castle shopping mall an it's transformed as a public bath.

So reintroducing bars as a public space and this this is quite interesting because I was trying to play with the idea for defining boundaries of individual and collective public and private and actually undertaking such a intimate act such as taking a bath can become quite a social.
A social action.

If the shower Q it could be 'cause they're all based on this idea of proximity.
So how?
How much space and distance I need to have between myself and the other people to feel at home?
And then there's this idea.
If you can pull it up and down to just be flagged reflexible, and if you want to hide yourself, you just take it down.
Otherwise you are just exposed.
So again, this idea of the bath.
It's a new form of social condenser where because you have no house, then you start spending more time in work at cafes in bus.
So how do you bring people together as well?
Just quickly the I design the Post office at Micro War, which is again and you massive structure which is then has smaller compartments for the individuals.
And zip Mail is this idea of like if you don't have a fixed address, how do you?
How do you get your post and hard?
Do you just collecting can order stuff from the Internet so it's kind of based on these Amazon lockers.
Idea of you can you can choose where your stuff is delivered.
So also through technology and an application there's this wayfinding.
System of unlocking and just like deciding where you want to pick up your post.
And zip microwave, which is quite dystopian.
As I said, it's just he said, yeah, we don't have kitchens, so we should take advantage of like the new ways of heating element in the city.
So these two people are meeting in front of the microwave.
Um?
And the third scale as I said, is the furniture level.
So this is the minimal backpack I've been using while I was doing my experiment.
So there's this idea of you can just carry minimal backpack and then it conceptually plugs into the building that are designed for Zip City.
So all the shampoos and all the towels they are all provided by the system and you just need to carry your minimal homely gadgets, let's say.
So in a way I know it's this is like a quite architectural project, but I imagine this project to be to kind of go across different.
Different aspects of living in the city, so he also thinks about who provides it.
Is it a public or public, public or private partnership?
Or is it just privately funded then?
Also, who uses it?
Is it more the young professionals or does it?
Does it actually becomes a new way of living also for families or the elderly?
And.
And also, do you need a membership?
Because obviously if you're not paying for housing anymore, how do you finance it?
So the project is really about turning this disadvantage condition of not having a house and the housing crisis into a positive one.
So reimagining and pushing to the limits.
This idea of leaving without a house and redefining the boundaries between all these different aspects of city life.
So yeah, thank you.
